title: Texas measles cases hit 561: Here's how it spreads and how to stay safe
summary: A significant measles outbreak has been reported in Texas with 561 confirmed cases. The news focuses on the spread of the disease and provides safety guidelines for the public.
content:
Texas is experiencing a concerning outbreak of measles with health officials reporting 561 confirmed cases across the state. The highly contagious virus spreads through respiratory droplets and can remain in the air for up to two hours after an infected person leaves an area.

Health experts emphasize the importance of vaccination as the most effective prevention method. The MMR vaccine provides 97% protection against measles when both recommended doses are received.

Symptoms typically appear 7-14 days after exposure and include high fever, cough, runny nose, and the characteristic red, blotchy rash. Officials advise anyone experiencing these symptoms to isolate and contact their healthcare provider immediately.

The Texas Department of Health Services is working closely with local authorities to contain the outbreak and has established emergency vaccination clinics in affected areas.

source.title: Texas measles cases hit 561: Here's how it spreads and how to stay safe

markdown_content:
## Current Outbreak Status
Texas is experiencing a concerning outbreak of measles with health officials reporting 561 confirmed cases across the state. The highly contagious virus spreads through respiratory droplets and can remain in the air for up to two hours after an infected person leaves an area.

## Prevention
Health experts emphasize the importance of vaccination as the most effective prevention method. The MMR vaccine provides 97% protection against measles when both recommended doses are received.

## Symptoms and Guidelines
Symptoms typically appear 7-14 days after exposure and include:
* High fever
* Cough
* Runny nose
* Characteristic red, blotchy rash

Officials advise anyone experiencing these symptoms to isolate and contact their healthcare provider immediately.

## Response Measures
The Texas Department of Health Services is working closely with local authorities to contain the outbreak and has established emergency vaccination clinics in affected areas.
